title.narrative: WASH and clean water initiatives in Jagobiao

description.narrative:
Specific project goal: Increased resilience of community groups and urban poor to cope with climate, environmental and social risks
By January 31, 2019, 10 clusters of households form groups implementing integrated community managed solid waste management, water access and WASH in the poorest and at most risk zones of Jagobiao and Socorro villages.
- At household level, 115 households (763 individuals) have access to toilets and safe and clean water
- At group level, 10 clusters apply community managed system for waste management and savings and credit mechanisms to support the communal facilities O&M system
- Documented model, impact and lessons for profiling, replication and investment

Targeting: 115 of the poorest households (763 people) in Jagobiao and Sitio Socorro with limited access to HH toilets and access to clean water that are exposed to regular flooding and unmanaged solid waste, geographically primarily targeting timberlands, fishponds and zones of the village which are the lowest lying zones of the village

The Philippines, an archipelago nation on the Pacific Rim, is highly exposed to the impacts of climate change. Under climate change scenarios according to the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration or PAGASA1 in 2018 it is projected that the Philippines will be affected by an increase in severity and frequency of extreme climate-related events, such as storms, sea-level rise, flooding, and drought in future decades. According to the PAGASA publication, current weather patterns already show greater evidence of climate change with longer lasting droughts, heavy and unpredictable precipitation events and the expansion of the typhoon belt. These events are already exceeding coping capacities of the poorest and most exposed communities in the Philippines. For many rural families facing increased pressure on natural resources, the seas and agricultural lands, combined with extreme climatic events, results in challenges in meeting basic needs. This subsequently increases rural-urban migration to major cities, Manila, Cebu, and Davao.
Within this context, particular focus has to be directed towards fast-growing urban centers as the speed of development and rural-urban migration outstrips city planning and infrastructure capacity. This leaves urban communities, in particular poor informal/slum settlements where the rural poor settle, at a higher risk. Extreme climatic events such as flooding in this setting are further compounded by limited infrastructure and drainage resulting in pollution and poor sanitation. For the poorest of the poor living in informal or slum settlements with limited access to basic drainage, water and sanitation, flooding impacts health, income opportunities and assets. Within the context of working with the urban poor it is especially important to work across administrative boundaries of communities; the formal structures of puroks, barangays and cities as their coastal zones, watersheds and drainage systems reflect an inter-administrative landscape.

mailing-address.narrative: Grote Marktstraat 45, Den Haag, Zuid Holland, 2511 BH

title.narrative: Number of Resilience Action Plans developed at community/local level

description.narrative: No. of communities which have been supported by Cordaid and/or partners and developed joint action plans to enhance resilience at the community/local level
No. of people who have been reached directly or indirectly by Cordaid and/or partners - i.e. people who have become more resilient to disasters and other risks

title.narrative: Number of communities implementing Resilience measures

description.narrative: No. of targeted communities which have been supported by Cordaid and/or partners and (raise funds for and) carry out their action plans by implementing resilience interventions at the community/ local level

title.narrative: Number of publications/other materials on enhanced (community) resilience ("evidence") made by CSO/NGO partners and/or field staff

description.narrative: Supported / funded by Cordaid private funds (MiN) or other backdonors (non-PfR)

title.narrative: Number of Participatory Disaster Risk Analysis (PDRAs) done at community/local level
